column1: Pruszcz Gdański (pronounced [pruʂtʂ ˈɡdaj̃skʲi]; former Polish: Pruszcz; German: Praust) is a town in Pomerania
column2: northwestern Poland with 26834 inhabitants (2010). Pruszcz Gdański is an industrial town neighbouring Gdańsk
column3: part of the Tricity agglomeration. The Tricity Circle Highway begins in Pruszcz Gdański.

column1: The capital of Gdańsk County in Pomeranian Voivodeship since 1999
column2: Pruszcz Gdański was a town in the Gdańsk Voivodeship from 1975 to 1998. Polish State Railways has a railway station in the town.

column1: The town was first mentioned as 'Prust'. The Polish government of the region employed the name Pruszcz until the town became part of Prussia as the result of the Partitions of Poland. For a couple of centuries Pruszcz was often visited by Polish kings
column2: during their travels to nearby Gdańsk.

column1: Between 1871 and 1920 Pruszcz as Praust was part of Germany. Unlike most of Eastern Pomerania
column2: the town did not return to Poland after regaining independence
column3: but was included in the short-lived Free City of Danzig by the Treaty of Versailles. During World War II
column4: Pruszcz was the location of Nazi Germany's Praust concentration camp
column5: a female subcamp of the Stutthof concentration camp. After the region was finally reintegrated with Poland in 1945
column6: the local German population was expelled. As early as 30 March 1945
column7: the Polish Post Office began its work as the first post-war Polish institution in the town. In post-war Poland the adjective Gdański was added to the town's name
column8: after the nearby city of Gdańsk
column9: to distinguish the town from other Polish settlements of the same name.

The clubs local football club is Czarni Pruszcz Gdański.
Edward Jurkiewicz (born 1948 in Pruszcz Gdański) a Polish former professional basketball player
Mateusz Bąk (born 1983 in Pruszcz Gdański) a Polish footballer who currently played for Lechia Gdańsk as a goalkeeper.
